text: hi everyone fall fashion here the
internet's busiest music nerd and it's
time for a review of the new Edge hearin
project Autumn variations this is a
brand new LP from singer songwriter Ed
Sheeran given Ed is one of the most
streamed artists on the planet living
today I don't know if he needs that much
of an introduction but I should give you
at least a little bit of pivotal
background uh to this new project for
one on this record Ed is going
independent
yay for sure he has most likely some big
distribution behind it but he has
released Autumn variations through his
own label gingerbread man you can't say
he's not self-aware but yeah creatively
Ed seems to be in full control of this
one and while I'm sure his extreme
success in the music industry has
allotted him a lot of creative freedom
already for sure on this one there is no
record exec breathing down his neck
saying Ed we need another shape of you
we need 10 more shape of you use
chaining the poor guy to the acoustic
guitar and with this label change Ed is
seemingly getting a little conceptual on
this one as the 14 tracks on this thing
are all supposed to be in tribute to uh
different friends or people in Ed's life
and various experiences that they've
been going through he also worked with
the Nationals Aaron dner on the
production with this LP who Ed has
collabed with before of course uh you
guys may also be familiar with Aaron's
work through uh the more Indie Centric
folk isms that have turned up on some of
Taylor Swift's latest work but sadly
those sounds those vibes don't really
bear out on this new LP actually there
are very little aesthetic or
instrumental surprises on this album at
all which I think says a lot about the
types of Aesthetics and instrumentation
that really drives Ed as an artist
because while absolutely there are no
tracks on this LP where Ed is uh
desperately trying for some kind of pop
singer songwriter crossover no surprise
rap vers veres on this thing no super
glitzy choruses or anything like that
what is left though is this a very brisk
but also Bland acoustic Pastiche that
varies between coffee shop open mic sad
boy ballads and Christian singer
songwriter rock tunes and that is when
he's not hitting us with something super
Deja Vu or even derivative like with
plastic bag the tune and instrumental on
this one feels like a combo of that song
he wrote for One Direction ages ago
little things but ALS o Peter Gabriel's
Salsbury Hill Ed shear and try not to
get sued challenge plus the layered
falsetto vocals all over the track blue
uh feel like Ed trying his best bony ver
impression but also with none of the
rustic Indie charm of Justin Vernon's
music so when it comes to the sound of
this thing I am neither thrilled or
impressed but I will say the tunes at
the core of these tracks aren't
necessarily bad I commend Ed for not
only coming together with a series of
pretty touching tributes on this thing
but also writing from the perspectives
of some of the people he has in mind on
these tracks whether he's relaying the
sense of hope and Adventure on living in
a new place and finding a new love on
American town or giving us a kind of
funny bit about birthdays meaning less
and less as you grow older that's on the
track the day I was born and there's
something also subtly sad about the loss
of togetherness around these sentimental
personal holidays and moments that Ed's
singing about with people in your life
often kind of growing a apart from you
or dealing with their own sometimes
Ed also sings about struggling with
sobriety and creativity on that's on me
which features one of the best and most
passionate vocal performances on the
entire record and with the song paig
there are also very genuine and
complicated feelings of uh Pride
worthlessness loneliness and regret that
are expressed there's a lot of layers to
this one emotionally more than I think
Ed often puts into his tracks and shout
out to the track amazing 2o which is all
about mental struggles had around this
this undefined illness Ed is singing
about harboring a lot of Shame over that
and getting in the way of your own
happiness by drowning in your Sorrows on
this project I think the biggest enemy
to Ed's songwriting here is some
occasionally unimaginative framing like
on the song England where I think Ed is
really trying to get across this sense
of national pride but the song just kind
of ends up reading like a tourism ad the
song spring to while I do understand its
feelings of fear and stagnant all these
themes of olation are dug down to in
only a very surface level way I think
and as a result I kind of get a feeling
of secondhand boredom from the song
overall Autumn variations is not a bad
one from Ed but conversely it's just not
a very adventurous or interesting record
musically though I am happy to not be
catching him with his hand in the I'm
trying to make a hit this is me making a
hit cookie jar but still I wish he would
Veer away just a little bit from the
overly clean and pristine Aesthetics all
the time especially with someone like
Aaron dner right there who knows and
understands the pathways from which you
could do that and still have the music
sound good and have a commercial appeal
but like Dan there's just a bit more
texture and maybe just folksy rusticness
to it that I think would work in the
context of Ed's music given he is a
singer songwriter I mean it is cool that
he's continuing to write from a very
personal place on this new record I just
wish the production felt a bit more
personal to him and just not so paint by
the Numbers I'm feeling a strong five to
a light six on this one TR ition have
